query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 La bocca sollevò dal fiero pasto 2 quel peccator, forbendola a’ capelli 3 del capo ch’elli avea di retro guasto.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The sinner raised his mouth from the savage meal, 2 wiping it on the hair 3 of the head that he had mangled at the back.
**Old English:**
1 Þa ðone muð of ðam wyrman aferede 2 se synfulla, and ongan ða hyrst berian 3 ðæs heafdes ðe he ær ofslytan wolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Poi cominciò: «Tu vuo’ ch’io rinovelli 5 disperato dolor che ’l cor mi preme 6 già pur pensando, pria ch’io ne favelli.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Then he began: "You wish that I renew 5 the desperate grief that weighs upon my heart, 6 even just thinking about it, before I speak of it.
**Old English:**
4 Þa ongan he secgan: "Þu woldest ðæt ic ðe eft arehte 5 wanhydigne geðoht ðe ðin heortan bregð, 6 ðurh ðone mode ðe ðu ðin mod geþencst, ær ðam ðe ðu ða spræce onginne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Ma se le mie parole esser dien seme 8 che frutti infamia al traditor ch’i’ rodo, 9 parlar e lagrimar vedrai insieme.
query.result:
**English:**
7 But if my words are to be seeds 8 that bear infamy for the traitor that I gnaw, 9 you will see speech and tears together.
**Old English:**
7 Ac gif ða word mine sceolon beon sæd 8 ðe ða wæstmas weaxað to wohþe ðæs forræderes ðe ic wrige, 9 ðu gesyhst spræce and tearas samod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Io non so chi tu se’ né per che modo 11 venuto se’ qua giù; ma fiorentino 12 mi sembri veramente quand’ io t’odo.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I do not know who you are or by what means 11 you have come down here; but you truly seem 12 to be a Florentine when I hear you speak.
**Old English:**
10 Ic nat hwa ðu eart ne ðurh hwæt ðu come 11 hider on ðisne grund; ac ðu ðuhte me 12 Florentinus to beonne ða ðu spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Tu dei saper ch’i’ fui conte Ugolino, 14 e questi è l’arcivescovo Ruggieri: 15 or ti dirò perché i son tal vicino.
query.result:
**English:**
13 You must know that I was Count Ugolino, 14 and this is Archbishop Ruggieri: 15 now I will tell you why I am such a neighbor to him.
**Old English:**
13 ðu scealt witan ðæt ic wæs eorl Ugolino, 14 and ðes is se arcebiscop Ruggieri: 15 nu ic ðe secge for hwi ic eom him swylc neahgebur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Breve pertugio dentro da la Muda, 23 la qual per me ha ’l titol de la fame, 24 e che conviene ancor ch’altrui si chiuda,
25 m’avea mostrato per lo suo forame 26 più lune già, quand’ io feci ’l mal sonno 27 che del futuro mi squarciò ’l velame.
query.result:
**English:**
22 A brief opening within the Muda, 23 which for me has the title of hunger, 24 and which is fitting that others should also be shut up in,
25 had shown me through its opening 26 many moons ago, when I had the evil dream 27 that tore away the veil of the future for me.
**Old English:**
22 Lytel hole binnan ðære cwearterne, 23 ðe for me hæfð ðone naman ðære hungre, 24 and ðe gerisen is ðæt oðre men ðær binnan sien belocene,
25 hæfde me æteowed ðurh ðæt gæt 26 fela monað ær, ða ic ðone yfelne swefn geseah 27 ðe me ðæs toweardan ðone wafels reafde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Questi pareva a me maestro e donno, 29 cacciando il lupo e ’ lupicini al monte 30 per che i Pisan veder Lucca non ponno.
query.result:
**English:**
28 This one seemed to me a master and lord, 29 chasing the wolf and the wolf cubs up the mountain 30 so that the Pisans cannot see Lucca.
**Old English:**
28 Þes me ðuhte ðæs læredes mannes gast 29 on ðam munte ða wulfas onwende, 30 ðæt ða Luccan ne meahton ða burh gehealdan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Con cagne magre, studïose e conte 32 Gualandi con Sismondi e con Lanfranchi 33 s’avea messi dinanzi da la fronte.
query.result:
**English:**
31 With lean, studious, and thoughtful hounds, 32 Gualandi with Sismondi and Lanfranchi 33 had placed himself in front of them.
**Old English:**
31 Mid hlænum, studendum, and geþancum hundum, 32 Gualandi mid Sismonde and Lanfrancum 33 hæfde gesett him beforan ða neb.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 In picciol corso mi parieno stanchi 35 lo padre e ’ figli, e con l’agute scane 36 mi parea lor veder fender li fianchi.
query.result:
**English:**
34 In a short run they seemed to me weary, 35 the father and the sons, and with sharp spurs 36 it seemed to me to see them pierce their flanks.
**Old English:**
34 On lytlum færelde hi ðuhte wæron wæge 35 se fæder and ða bearn, and mid scearpum sporum 36 ðuhte ðæt hi ða sidan him sylfum wæron slægende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Quando fui desto innanzi la dimane, 38 pianger senti’ fra ’l sonno i miei figliuoli 39 ch’eran con meco, e dimandar del pane.
query.result:
**English:**
37 When I awoke the next morning, 38 I heard my children weeping in their sleep, 39 who were with me, and asking for bread.
**Old English:**
37 Þa ic æfter ðam on mergenne awoc, 38 ða ic gehyrde on slæpe wepan mine cild, 39 ða þe mid me wæron, and hi wæron hlāfes biddende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Ben se’ crudel, se tu già non ti duoli 41 pensando ciò che ’l mio cor s’annunziava; 42 e se non piangi, di che pianger suoli?
43 Già eran desti, e l’ora s’appressava 44 che ’l cibo ne solëa essere addotto, 45 e per suo sogno ciascun dubitava;
46 e io senti’ chiavar l’uscio di sotto 47 a l’orribile torre; ond’ io guardai 48 nel viso a’ mie’ figliuoi sanza far motto.
query.result:
**English:**
40 You are indeed cruel if you do not grieve 41 thinking of what my heart was foretelling; 42 and if you do not weep, at what are you accustomed to weeping?
43 They were already awake, and the hour was approaching 44 when food used to be brought to us, 45 and because of his dream each one was apprehensive;
46 and I heard the door of the tower below being locked 47 so I looked 48 in the faces of my sons without saying a word.
**Old English:**
40 Þu eart to ðæs heard, gif ðu ðe nu ne ofhreowsest 41 ðonne ðu ðincasð hwæt ðin heorte ðe bodede; 42 and gif ðu ne wepest, hwæs wenst ðu ðonne to wepenne?
43 Hi wæron ða awæhte, and seo tid wæs gehende 44 ðe him mon æt gehwilcere tide heora bigleofan brohte, 45 and hi ðurh ðone swefn ealle swiðe ondredon;
46 and ic ða gehyrde ðæt man ða dura beloc, 47 ða de to ðam torran lædde; ða ic on ða wlite 48 minra suna locade, and ne gespræc nænig word.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Io non piangëa, sì dentro impetrai: 50 piangevan elli; e Anselmuccio mio 51 disse: “Tu guardi sì, padre! che hai?”.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I did not weep, so turned to stone within: 50 they wept; and my little Anselm said: 51 “What ails you, father! what are you staring at?”.
**Old English:**
49 Ic ne weop na, swa ic wæs innan forsteined: 50 weopon ða ða ðe ðær wæron; and min Anselm 51 cwæð: “Hwæt locast ðu, fæder! hwæt is ðe?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Perciò non lagrimai né rispuos’ io 53 tutto quel giorno né la notte appresso, 54 infin che l’altro sol nel mondo uscìo.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Therefore I did not weep nor did I answer 53 all that day nor the night after, 54 until the other sun came out into the world.
**Old English:**
52 Forðæm ic ne weop næfre ne ic andswarode 53 ealne ðone dæg ne ða niht ða æfter, 54 oððæt ðæt oder sunne on ðone world com.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Come un poco di raggio si fu messo 56 nel doloroso carcere, e io scorsi 57 per quattro visi il mio aspetto stesso,
58 ambo le man per lo dolor mi morsi; 59 ed ei, pensando ch’io ’l fessi per voglia 60 di manicar, di sùbito levorsi
61 e disser: “Padre, assai ci fia men doglia 62 se tu mangi di noi: tu ne vestisti 63 queste misere carni, e tu le spoglia”.
query.result:
**English:**
55 As soon as a little ray of light had entered 56 the sorrowful prison, and I saw 57 my own face reflected in four faces,
58 I bit both my hands in grief; 59 and he, thinking that I did it out of a desire 60 to eat, suddenly rose up
61 and said: “Father, it will be much less painful for us 62 if you eat of us: you clothed us 63 with this wretched flesh, and you strip it off.”
**Old English:**
55 Swa sum ðæs liðan lyt swylce wæs 56 on ðam wyrmsele wædlum forðgesceaft, 57 ðæt ic ða geseah ðurh ða swyðran gesceaft
58 feower feðan minum gelice, 59 ða ic ða ongan earmlic murcnan, 60 ða ða ic ða geseah ða hyldo minre
61 ðurh ða gesceaft ðe ðær gescyred wæs, 62 ða ic ða ongan ða earman biddan 63 ðæt hie ða gesceaft ðurh ða gescyredan gesceaft
64 ðurh ða gesceaft ðe ðær gescyred wæs 65 ðurh ða gesceaft ðe ðær gescyred wæs 66 ðurh ða gesceaft ðe ðær gescyred wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Queta’mi allor per non farli più tristi; 65 lo dì e l’altro stemmo tutti muti; 66 ahi dura terra, perché non t’apristi?
67 Poscia che fummo al quarto dì venuti, 68 Gaddo mi si gittò disteso a’ piedi, 69 dicendo: “Padre mio, ché non m’aiuti?”.
query.result:
**English:**
64 I was silent then, so as not to make them sadder; 65 the day and the next we remained all silent; 66 ah, hard earth, why did you not open up?
67 After we had reached the fourth day, 68 Gaddo threw himself down at my feet, 69 saying: “Father, why do you not help me?”
**Old English:**
64 Þa wæs ic stylle for ðære sorgæ, 65 ðone dæg and ðone ōðerne wē wæron ealle dūmbe; 66 ealā ðū hearda eorðe, hwi ne tū ðe tōslīte?
67 Siððan wē wæron tō ðam fēorðan dæge cumen, 68 þā Gaddo wearð mē tō fōtum feallende, 69 and cwæð: “Fæder mīnum, hwi ne helpest ðū mē?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Quivi morì; e come tu mi vedi, 71 vid’ io cascar li tre ad uno ad uno 72 tra ’l quinto dì e ’l sesto; ond’ io mi diedi,
73 già cieco, a brancolar sovra ciascuno, 74 e due dì li chiamai, poi che fur morti.
query.result:
**English:**
70 There he died; and as you see me, 71 I saw the three of them fall one by one 72 between the fifth and sixth day; whereupon I gave myself,
73 already blind, to groping over each one, 74 and for two days I called to them, after they were dead.
**Old English:**
70 Þær he swalt; and swa ðu me gesyhst, 71 ic geseah ða ðreo feallan anra gehwylcne 72 betwux ðam fiftan dæge and ðam syxtan; þa ic me sealde,
73 ða blind, to gropiande ofer gehwylcne, 74 and twegen dagas ic hig clypode, syððan hie deade wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
75 Poscia, più che ’l dolor, poté ’l digiuno».
76 Quand’ ebbe detto ciò, con li occhi torti 77 riprese ’l teschio misero co’ denti, 78 che furo a l’osso, come d’un can, forti.
query.result:
**English:**
75 Afterward, hunger was more powerful than grief.
76 When he had said this, with twisted eyes 77 he seized the wretched skull with his teeth, 78 which were strong against the bone, like a dog’s.
**Old English:**
75 Siððan, má þonne seó sár, mihte seó fæsten.
76 Þá he ðæt gesæde, mid þám teónum wlítum 77 eft ongan se earmlic heafodceorl gnístan, 78 þe wáron tó þám bánum fáge swá hundes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Ahi Pisa, vituperio de le genti 80 del bel paese là dove ’l sì suona, 81 poi che i vicini a te punir son lenti,
82 muovasi la Capraia e la Gorgona, 83 e faccian siepe ad Arno in su la foce, 84 sì ch’elli annieghi in te ogne persona!
85 Che se ’l conte Ugolino aveva voce 86 d’aver tradita te de le castella, 87 non dovei tu i figliuoi porre a tal croce.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Ah Pisa, disgrace of the peoples 80 of the fair land where the sì is spoken, 81 since your neighbors are slow to punish you,
82 may Capraia and Gorgona move, 83 and make a hedge for the Arno at its mouth, 84 so that it may drown every person in you!
85 For if Count Ugolino was rumored 86 to have betrayed you of your castles, 87 you should not have put his children to such a cross.
**Old English:**
79 Eala Pisan, yrmðu ðara leoda 80 ðæs fægran landes ðær ðæt geap sigefæst, 81 nu ða neahgeburas sindon to sleac ðe to wrecanne,
82 gewurðe ðæt Capraia and Gorgona, 83 and wyrceð hecg ðam Arnan æt ðam muðan, 84 swa ðæt he adrence ælcne monn on ðe!
85 Gif ðe eorl Ugolino hæfde hlisan 86 ðæt he ðe beswice ðinra ceastra, 87 ne sceolde ðu ða bearn settan to swylcum geleafan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Innocenti facea l’età novella, 89 novella Tebe, Uguiccione e ’l Brigata 90 e li altri due che ’l canto suso appella.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Their youthful age made them innocent, 89 the new Thebes, Uguiccione and the Brigata, 90 and the other two whom the song above mentions.
**Old English:**
88 Unscyldige worhte ða ða geongan gear, 89 niwe Thebas, Uguiccione and ða Brygada, 90 and ða oðre twegen ðe ðæt leoð ær nemde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Noi passammo oltre, là ’ve la gelata 92 ruvidamente un’altra gente fascia, 93 non volta in giù, ma tutta riversata.
query.result:
**English:**
91 We passed onward, where the frost 92 binds another people harshly, 93 not turned downward, but all lying supine.
**Old English:**
91 We forð gewendon, ðær ðæs forstes gryre 92 wætre beworpen wæron yðe, 93 ne on bæc weard, ac on breostum læg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 E avvegna che, sì come d’un callo, 101 per la freddura ciascun sentimento 102 cessato avesse del mio viso stallo,
103 già mi parea sentire alquanto vento; 104 per ch’io: «Maestro mio, questo chi move? 105 non è qua giù ogne vapore spento?».
query.result:
**English:**
100 And although, as from a callus, 101 because of the cold every sensation 102 had ceased from its place on my face,
103 already it seemed to me that I felt a little wind; 104 so I said: "My Master, what moves this? 105 Isn't every vapor down here extinguished?"
**Old English:**
100 And ðeah ðe, swa swa of calle, 101 ðurh ða cealdness ælc geðoht 102 geðwæred hæfde mines ansynes stalles,
103 ða ðuhte me ðæt ic mihte lyt gehýran wind; 104 for ðon ic: "Láreow mín, hwæt ðis hwyrfð? 105 Nis her niðe ælc wæta aworpen?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Ond’ elli a me: «Avaccio sarai dove 107 di ciò ti farà l’occhio la risposta, 108 veggendo la cagion che ’l fiato piove».
query.result:
**English:**
106 And he said to me: "Soon you will be where 107 your eyes will give you the answer to this, 108 seeing the cause that makes the air rain down."
**Old English:**
106 And he sæde to me: " sona ðu byst ðær 107 ðin eage ðe ðæs andsware sylleð, 108 ðurh ðæt ðu gesyhst ðone grund ðe ðone wind sendð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 E un de’ tristi de la fredda crosta 110 gridò a noi: «O anime crudeli 111 tanto che data v’è l’ultima posta,
112 levatemi dal viso i duri veli, 113 sì ch’ïo sfoghi ’l duol che ’l cor m’impregna, 114 un poco, pria che ’l pianto si raggeli».
query.result:
**English:**
109 And one of the wretches from the cold crust 110 cried out to us: "O souls so cruel 111 that the last resting place has been given to you,
112 lift the hard veils from my face, 113 so that I may vent the grief that fills my heart, 114 a little, before my weeping congeals."
**Old English:**
109 And an ðara wrecca of ðam cealdan hrusan 110 clypode to us: "Eala, sawla swa grimme 111 ðæt eow is forgifen seo læste reste,
112 afyrrað ða heardan wæfelsa of minum ansyne, 113 swa ðæt ic amæte ðone dole ðe ðone heortan minne afylð, 114 lytle hwile, ærðam ðe ðæt weop forwurde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Per ch’io a lui: «Se vuo’ ch’i’ ti sovvegna, 116 dimmi chi se’, e s’io non ti disbrigo, 117 al fondo de la ghiaccia ir mi convegna».
query.result:
**English:**
115 Wherefore I said to him: "If you wish me to remember you, 116 tell me who you are, and if I do not free you, 117 may I be forced to go to the bottom of the ice."
**Old English:**
115 Forðæm ic him to cwæð: "Gif ðu wylt ðæt ic ðe gemæne, 116 sege me hwa ðu sy, and gif ic ðe ne alyse, 117 to ðæs ises grunde ic mote gangan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Rispuose adunque: «I’ son frate Alberigo; 119 i’ son quel da le frutta del mal orto, 120 che qui riprendo dattero per figo».
query.result:
**English:**
118 Then he replied: "I am Brother Alberigo; 119 I am the one from the fruits of the evil garden, 120 who here takes dates for figs."
**Old English:**
118 Þa andswarode he: "Ic eom broðor Alberig; 119 ic eom se ðe ða wæstan æppla, 120 ðe her ða ficum ða wæstan becernað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 «Oh», diss’ io lui, «or se’ tu ancor morto?». 122 Ed elli a me: «Come ’l mio corpo stea 123 nel mondo sù, nulla scïenza porto.
query.result:
**English:**
121 "Oh," I said to him, "are you still dead?" 122 And he to me: "How my body fares 123 in the world above, I have no knowledge."
**Old English:**
121 "Eala," cwæð ic him, "eart ðu gyt deað?" 122 And he to me: "Hu min lichama fare 123 on ðære worulde uppe, næbbe ic nane gewitnesse."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Cotal vantaggio ha questa Tolomea, 125 che spesse volte l’anima ci cade 126 innanzi ch’Atropòs mossa le dea.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Such advantage has this Tolomea, 125 that often the soul falls there 126 before Atropos gives it leave.
**Old English:**
124 Swylc foregæð hæfð ðeos Tolomea, 125 ðæt oft ðær sawel on fealleð 126 ærðon ðe Atropos hyre orlof sylle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 E perché tu più volentier mi rade 128 le ’nvetrïate lagrime dal volto, 129 sappie che, tosto che l’anima trade
130 come fec’ ïo, il corpo suo l’è tolto 131 da un demonio, che poscia il governa 132 mentre che ’l tempo suo tutto sia vòlto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 And so that you more willingly wipe away 128 the frozen tears from your face, 129 know that, as soon as the soul leaves,
130 as I did, a demon takes its body 131 and rules over it 132 until its allotted time is fully spent.
**Old English:**
127 And forðæm ðu ðe geornlicor mine 128 ða forsteortægru of ðinum wlite awyrpe, 129 wita ðæt sona swa ðeos sawul gewited,
130 swa ic dyde, ðonne bið hire lichama genumen 131 fram ðam deofle, se ðonne ðone lichaman gewealdeð 132 oð ðæt his tima eal gewended sie.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Ella ruina in sì fatta cisterna; 134 e forse pare ancor lo corpo suso 135 de l’ombra che di qua dietro mi verna.
query.result:
**English:**
133 She fell into such a cistern; 134 and perhaps her body still appears above 135 from the shadow that covers me from behind.
**Old English:**
133 Heo feoll on ða cisterne; 134 and ðeah ðæs lichoman sceadu ðær ða gyt lyfað 135 ðe me ðurh ðone hrycg wyrmde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Tu ’l dei saper, se tu vien pur mo giuso: 137 elli è ser Branca Doria, e son più anni 138 poscia passati ch’el fu sì racchiuso».
query.result:
**English:**
136 You should know this, if you have just come down here: 137 he is Ser Branca Doria, and it has been more years 138 since he was shut in here».
**Old English:**
136 ðu scealt ðæt witan, gif ðu nu her nyðer cume: 137 he is Ser Branca Doria, and sindon ma þonne 138 gear agon ðæt he wæs swa belocen».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 «Io credo», diss’ io lui, «che tu m’inganni; 140 ché Branca Doria non morì unquanche, 141 e mangia e bee e dorme e veste panni».
query.result:
**English:**
139 "I believe," I said to him, "that you are deceiving me; 140 for Branca Doria never died, 141 and he eats and drinks and sleeps and wears clothes."
**Old English:**
139 "Ic gelyfe," cwæð ic him, "ðæt ðu me swicst; 140 forðæmðe Branca Doria næfre ne swalt, 141 and he ett and drincð and slæpð and wæda werð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 «Nel fosso sù», diss’ el, «de’ Malebranche, 143 là dove bolle la tenace pece, 144 non era ancora giunto Michel Zanche,
145 che questi lasciò il diavolo in sua vece 146 nel corpo suo, ed un suo prossimano 147 che ’l tradimento insieme con lui fece.
query.result:
**English:**
142 "In the ditch below," he said, "of Malebranche, 143 where the sticky pitch boils, 144 Michel Zanche had not yet arrived,
145 for whom the devil left his body 146 to a demon, and one of his relatives 147 who committed the treachery with him.
**Old English:**
142 "On ðæm dic ðær neoðan," cwæð he, "ðara Malacoda, 143 ðær ðæt ðicce pic blacað, 144 nis na gyt cumen Michel Sanche,
145 ðone deofol forlêt on his agenre lichaman 146 deofle oðrum, and his agenre mæge 147 ðe ðæt swicdom mid him geworhte."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 Ahi Genovesi, uomini diversi 152 d’ogne costume e pien d’ogne magagna, 153 perché non siete voi del mondo spersi?
154 Ché col peggiore spirto di Romagna 155 trovai di voi un tal, che per sua opra 156 in anima in Cocito già si bagna,
157 e in corpo par vivo ancor di sopra.
query.result:
**English:**
151 Ah, Genoese, men different 152 in every custom and full of every evil, 153 why are you not scattered from the world?
154 For with the worst spirit of Romagna 155 I found one of you, who for his deeds 156 is already bathing his soul in Cocytus,
157 and in body still seems alive above.
**Old English:**
151 Eala, Genoware, men mislice 152 ælces þeawes and fulle yfles, 153 hwi ne synt ge of worulde aworpene?
154 Forðæm mid ðæm wyrrestan gaste of Romanie 155 ic funde ænne of eow, se ðurh his weorc 156 on sawle on Cocytus nu baðað,
157 and on lichaman leofað gyt ofer eorðan.
